docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, March 22-- The joint Congressional committee that has taken over La Prensa issued a statement today saying that the paper's director, Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, apparently had fled to avoid arrest. The committee accused him of obstructing...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, March 22-- The joint Congressional committee that has taken over La Prensa issued a statement today saying that the paper's director, Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, apparently had fled to avoid arrest. The committee accused him of obstructing justice.
docs.abstract: Cong com says Gainza has fled; Paz bars Foreign Mins discussion; holds it domestic issue

headline.main: Publisher of La Prensa Has Fled, Argentine Unit Running Paper Says; PRENSA PUBLISHER ACCUSED OF FLIGHT

byline.original: By VIRGINIA LEE WARREN Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23--The nickel, evicted from the subway turnstiles and not good enough by half for a phone call, still has enough buying power to keep a member of the United Nations in good standing.

headline.main: Lowly Nickel Can Do Big Things in U.N.; One Keeps Paraguay in Good Standing

byline.original: By A. M. ROSENTHAL Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, March 23-- The Federal police are reported to be watching all trains, automobiles and planes throughout Argentina in an effort to apprehend Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, whose arrest was ordered Wednesday night by the Congressional committee...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, March 23-- The Federal police are reported to be watching all trains, automobiles and planes throughout Argentina in an effort to apprehend Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, whose arrest was ordered Wednesday night by the Congressional committee that has taken over the newspaper La Prensa.
docs.abstract: police search for Gainza; his assocs trailed; Rio de Janeiro Correio da Manha urges UN action; Brit Natl Journalists Union scores Govt actions

headline.main: Publisher of La Prensa Thought to Be in Uruguay

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 24.--Once again Argentina is going into an international conference, slightly set apart from her twenty neighbors in the Americas. This time President Juan D. Peron's implacable fight against the newspaper La Prensa has had...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 24.--Once again Argentina is going into an international conference, slightly set apart from her twenty neighbors in the Americas. This time President Juan D. Peron's implacable fight against the newspaper La Prensa has had world-wide repercussions and touched off a battle of historic proportions for freedom of the press.
docs.abstract: Latin-Amer countries oppose Peron action against Prensa but are wary of open attack on him; cartoon
